title: Inkjet printing thin-film electronic devices from solution-based inks

author: Aleksander Matavž, Condensed Matter Physics Department, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Thank you so I will talk about printing electronics.
So did you know that for a chip that is found in this device, it takes industry 1500 individual processing steps to make it an even for the microphone?
It takes them 300.
This is mainly due to the fact that.
OK, I'll be here.
This is mainly due to the fact that the position is done in 6 steps, so we have heard the position of the material and then we have to pattern this step.
This is time consuming and it's also very expensive so we can see that nearly 80% of the whole costs comes from this position and patterning.
So we can ask ourselves, can we do better?
And of course the answer is yes we can.
We can use printed electronics, so in this printer.
One is the whole step is the whole procedure is just one step, so we have the position of the material and patterning all done at once.
So in this way we get rid of all this unnecessary expensive expenses, and we can also get some very unique characteristics.
For example, no physical patterning is required as a set, and printing printed electronics is really suitable for large area electronics.
This is the new field that we haven't seen yet in large extent, but what is most important is that we can do all this at extremely low.

Costs so if you ask me if I will be printing your new microprocessor, I would say no, that's ridiculous, but it might happen that this industry will focus on smart windows, which are actually like phones but in size of the whole window.
This is called transparent electronics and it could be also possible to print solar cells.
So this technology would become really cheap.
One of the technique.
To print stuff is inkjet printing.
You might know it, you might have it back at home, you for sure printed some documents with it and it's based on the really simple simple principle.
The principle is that we have formation of really small drops and redeposit is drops on the substrate and the whole process is computer guided.
So we can change the pattern on the computer.
It's really easy to change it, it's fast, it's versatile and it's flexible.
Because of this properties, it's also suitable for.
Rapid prototyping for up to now we already deposited dielectric structures with deposit that silver electrodes with deposit that we fabricate the transparent capacitors, which is kind of cool.
And if you get creative you can also make graffiti what we did but don't tell anybody about it and you can Make Love nodes.
So it's up to you.
So because you cannot.
Graduate or make a PhD from Love notes and making graffiti.
I focused on printing metal oxides from a solution.
This way we get structures that are really non mitterteich.
We can easily modify the composition but there are some fundamental issues with this technique because otherwise everybody would be using it of course.
So in my poster I'm focusing on this particular issues waiting on the substrate and eliminating coffee stain effect which is shown here and I will conclude now so.
If you are interested you can email me.
You can add me on ResearchGate or even better.
Come to my poster under the number 51.
Thank you.
